Why is it tagged simply "x86" if it doesn't work on the 64-bit version of Vista? 64-bit x86 CPUs are still, well, x86.

And where does this x64 nonsense come from? There's no xxx64 family of processors that I know of, and certainly none the is supported by Vista.

"x86-64" and "x86-32" would be proper ways to denote Intel ISA x86 compatible CPUs of the 64 and 32-bit variety, respectively.

Sorry for the rant, but I did expect this to work on 64-bit versions too.

@Sarre, where have you been for the last three years?
Microsoft (and Sun) has been calling it x64 for years meaning that it will run on both AMD64 and EM64T - so as not to confuse with IA-64.
Anyway, it says so like that in Windows Vista and XP.
Don't blame others for your own ignorance. If you're to stupid to search Google, just go on buy the license - you'd definitely need the support.

I got the same BSOD, with Royal.sys as the issue... had to do the same thing as other poster, last good config, and I was back fine... Any other ideas ?

The BSOD error is caused by the Update from Microsoft named
Nforce4 PCI-Express Root Port (also included in Nvidia drivers).

This is a guide to solve the problem: 


1. If you got the BSOD, find a way (safemode or dualboot)
   to rename the file in \windows\system32\drivers\royal.sys to royal2.sys

2. Your should not get the BSOD the next time you restart.
   Go to Control panel -> Device Manager.

3. Under System Devices you should see the Nforce4 PCI-Express Root Port.

4. Right-click and choose Properties.

5. Under the Driver tab choose Roll Back Driver.

6. BEFORE you restart rename \windows\system32\drivers\royal2.sys back to royal.sys

7. Restart now and it should be activated!

When will we see 64 bit version??

Here's my rant.  Why do people want the x64 version of Vista?  It's like the 64-bit version of Windows XP --- CRAP.  There's very few native 64-bit programs and won't be for years.  And I've seen benchmarks where trying to run 32-bit programs with 64-bit XP actually runs SLOWER than running the 32-bit programs with 32-bit XP.  

The only advantage a 64-bit Windows has (XP or Vista) is when it's running a native 64-bit app.  And those are few and far between.  

So, best to stick with the 32-bit (x86) Vista until there's a much better inventory available.
I activated Vista with this, but Microsoft Word still wants a product key.  I entered the one from the .nfo, doesn't work.  Ideas?
mattchazz: Those benchmarks are indeed true for Windows XP, but you should go and read up and look into similar ones for Vista.... HUUUUGE difference.
Also, atm I'm running eleven 32-bit processes and ten 64-bit processes. So the assumption that there wont be 64-bit apps for YEARS ahead belongs in a trashcan.

This Crack does in fact work.

When installing, as per the instructions, do NOT enter a key.

Also, when given the option to "protect your PC" opt for the manual configuration option.  You do not want updates applied until you've run this.

If you have an NForce2 or 4 chipset you also have to be very careful as the latest PCI Bus Management (as per march 2008) or if you have NForce4, do not install Nforce4 PCI-Express Root Port, the problem is apparently with some buggy NVidia drivers and not with Vista or the Crack itself, this applies for both the CLoNY crack and the PARADOX crack.

A huge shout out to CLoNY and PARADOX for a job well done.

If you're wondering whether or not you want to move from XP to Vista, consider the following:

Vista is running great on my 3000+ Atlon XP (single 32-bit core) system with 2GB dual channel RAM and a GForce 7300GT (AGP) GFX Card.  So far, as far as User Experience Level Goes, I'm at a 3.6 mainly because my CPU is getting that rating and it is the lowest, everything else is at a 4.2 or higher (HDD Transfer rate is 5.2 and thei're all IDE).

All told this is a 4 year old machine i'm running.  Hardly cutting edge technology.
